subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: RBA Lowe comments temper October rate cut calls, Treasury Wine Estates considers spinning off commercial wine operations, SoftBank Corp receives 5G license
content:
AUSTRALIA

AGL Energy (AGL AT) - Co. enters supply agreement with Esso. (Newswires)

Fonterra (FSF AT) - Co. is to sell 50% stake in DFE Pharma for NZD 633mln. (Newswires)

Mount Gibson Iron (MGX AT) - Co. total mineral resources estimate at 74.2mln tonnes vs. last year’s estimate of 76.4mln tonnes in which it cited mining depletion for the reduction in estimates. (Newswires)

OceanaGold (OGC AT) - Co. significantly raised exploration target at the Martha Underground mine in New Zealand. (Newswires)

Retail Food Group (RFG AT) - Co. is thought to be mulling a capital raise. (Newswires)

Senex Energy (SXY AT) - EIG offloaded 131.8mln shares in the Co. at AUD 0.37/Shr vs. last close AUD 0.40/Shr. (Newswires)

Strike Energy (STX AT) - Co. appointed Neville Power as Deputy Chairman. (Newswires)

Treasury Wine Estates (TWE AT) - Co. is said to be considering spinning off its cheaper commercial-wine operations from higher end business. (Newswires)

Wise Tech (WTC AT) - Co. is said to be well positioned to achieve its FY20 EBITDA and revenue guidance. (Newswires)

Other News - RBA Governor Lowe said fundamental factors underpinning the longer-term outlook for the Australian economy remain strong and the economy has reached a gentle turning point. Lowe reiterated that the Board is prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy, make further progress towards full employment and achieve the inflation target over time, while he added that inflation is expected to pick up but will remain below the midpoint of the target range for some time to come. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Asahi Co. (3333 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 2.6bln vs. Prev. JPY 2.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi UFJ Securities (8615 JT) - Co. is said to be finalizing job cuts in Singapore, Hong Kong and Australia in which it plans to reduce half of Asia ex-Japan staff. (Newswires)

Nintendo (7974 JT) - Co. reportedly sold 63k Switch units last week and September 20th-22nd Switch Lite sales are seen at 114k units. (Newswires)

Nitori (9843 JT) - Co. September same store sales rose 19.5% Y/Y, while it was also reported the Co. H1 oper. profit may fall 2% Y/Y to JPY 55bln. (Nikkei)

Oracle Corp (4716 JT) - Co. Q1 parent net JPY 9.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 9.4bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Shimamura (8227 JT) - Co. September same store sales fell 4.4% Y/Y. (Newswires)

SoftBank Corp (9434 JT) - Co. awarded 5G license in Japan. (Newswires)

Autos - Japan is planning to put US auto tariff removal in trade agreement, while it was also reported that Japan and US failed to reach an agreement on US tariff removal timeline. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Heavy (009540 KS) - Co. unit receives KRW 159bln order for crude carriers. (Yonhap)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. introduced the industry’s first 0.7 micron-pixel image sensor. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea's Vice Finance Minister said the government will help create jobs in the private sector through innovation and deregulation. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said the US is seeking justice regarding trade with China and that the WTO needs drastic change given China's actions on trade, while there were separate reports China is to keep supporting pork and soybean purchases from the US. (Newswires/Xinhua)

RBA Governor Lowe said fundamental factors underpinning the longer-term outlook for the Australian economy remain strong and the economy has reached a gentle turning point. Lowe reiterated that the Board is prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy, make further progress towards full employment and achieve the inflation target over time, while he added that inflation is expected to pick up but will remain below the midpoint of the target range for some time to come. (Newswires)

US President Trump expects a trade deal with India "very soon", while there were separate comments from China's new ambassador to India that China has called for a free trade pact with India to fast track business ties. (Newswires/Hindustan Times)

 

UK/EU

UK Supreme Court ruled that the prorogation of parliament is a matter for the judges and that PM Johnson's prorogation of parliament was unlawful as well as void, while it also stated that no justification for such extreme action has been heard and the Government have not explained why it was necessary to halt parliament for 5-weeks. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said that he strongly disagrees with the decision but respects the judicial process and suggested there are a lot of people who want to frustrate Brexit. Furthermore, it was also reported that PM Johnson will not abandon his attempt to secure Brexit by October 31st following the Supreme Court ruling according to government sources. (Twitter/ITV)

UK Speaker of the House of Commons Bercow will announce recall of Parliament first thing tomorrow at 1130BST. (Twitter/ITV)

UK government source expects a quick push for an election again perhaps even as early as this week, although the source added that it won’t fly until UK PM Johnson agrees an extension. (Twitter/Sky)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier said he sees no reason for optimism that Britain and the EU can find a solution to questions over the Irish backstop. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar said following meeting with UK PM Johnson that there were no Brexit agreements by any means however they did get into further details. (Newswires)

EU diplomats noted that a Brexit extension would likely take the pressure off both sides to make compromises necessary to agree a new deal, while they are said to be unsure whether UK PM Johnson is willing to make compromises if the UK is heading to a general election. (Twitter/BBC)

US President Trump said the US can quadruple its trade with Britain and UK PM Johnson reiterated he hopes to make quick progress with the US regarding trade. (Newswires)

ECB's de Guindos said we are facing a more protracted economic slowdown than was previously expected and that there is very little evidence of this priced in by markets. ECB's de Guindos also stated that long term inflation expectations are low and noted signs of a somewhat tighter labour market, while he added policy should be based on a variety of factors. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

API Crude Inventories: +1.4mln vs. Exp. -0.2mln (Prev. +0.6mln). (Newswires)

Saudi Aramco's trading arm is reportedly seeking crude oil from neighbouring countries to supply foreign refineries, according to sources. In other news, sources stated that Saudi Aramco is unlikely to go through with its IPO this year amid the attacks on its oil facilities. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi Foreign Minister said they will consider all options including military after the completion of the probe into the attack on Saudi oil facilities. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the sanctions on Iran will not be lifted and will be tightened as long as Iran is continuing to undertake their menacing behaviour. (Newswires)

Iran's President Rouhani said he is open to the discussion of small changes, additions and/or amendments to the nuclear deal but in the scenario that sanctions are lifted. (Newswires)

The Stena Impero tanker and crew are reportedly still detained in Iran despite reports yesterday that Iran announced the vessel is free to leave. (Twitter/Sky)

 

US

US House Speaker Pelosi said the House is to open formal impeachment inquiry on President Trump, while she added that Trump’s actions have seriously violated the constitution and that he must be held accountable. Pelosi also commented that Trump's call with the Ukraine President marked breach of constitutional responsibilities and that the administration's effort to block release of whistle blower report was a violation of law.  Furthermore, the House will vote on Wednesday on Trump condemnation motion and there were also reports the US Senate approved resolution for whistle blower complaint to be submitted to Senate and House Intel Committees. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he will release the 'fully declassified and unredacted transcript' of his phone conversation with the Ukrainian President, while he also suggested the Democrats purposely had to ruin and demean an important and successful day at the United Nations with a witch hunt and called it presidential harassment. (Newswires/Twitter)

NY Fed accepted USD 75bln of USD 80.20bln bids submitted for its overnight repo operation and accepted USD 30bln of USD 62bln bids submitted at its first 14-day term repo operation. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said he pushed for a larger rate cut at the September FOMC and commented that the job market has slowed markedly. (Newswires)

US Consumer Confidence (Sep) 125.1 vs. Exp. 133.5 (Prev. 135.1, Rev. 134.2). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) initially traded in the green following an upgrade at Jefferies; the tech behemoth also likely benefitting from a Digi Times article stating its iPhone 11 demand has exceeded expectations in Taiwan. Gains were pared back as it followed Tuesday’s general cautious market tone. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) an outperformer following an upgrade at Goldman Sachs. CarMax (KMX) initially were an outperformer, however, gains reversed as it tracked the overall risk-off tone. The semiconductor index (SOX) initially opened higher also, coinciding with some positive research from RBC, which suggested both NAND and DRAM pricing has bottomed, and are showing signs of a rebound; however it also became susceptible to the overall risk tone and drifted lower throughout the session. AMD (AMD) were under pressure as initial reports suggest it delayed its Ryzen 9 3950 X launch, however AMD announced that it is focusing on meeting strong demand for its Ryzen processes and that it is planning to launch both AMD Ryzen 9 3950 X and 3rd generation threadripper processer family in volume from November. Social media names (FB, TWTR) came under scrutiny again from US President Trump who announced social media companies are weakening the democratic rule. Consumer names (TGT, M, WMT) all hit by poor consumer confidence data, and housing names (LEN, PHM, TOL) firmer following mixed housing data, Case Shiller missed expectations and slowed from the prior however FHFA was firmer, beating expectations. Tesla (TSLA) was pressured as its rival, Nio (NIO) fell 25% after it posted a quarterly drop in sales, citing a cut in subsidies and weak demand for the decline. S&P 500 -0.8% AT 2967, NASDAQ-100 -1.4% AT 7710, DOW JONES  -0.5% AT 26812.

The curve was mixed, at settlement; although yields are lower across the curve, 2s5s, 2s10s and 2s30s spreads are slightly narrower, while 5s10s, 5s30s and 10s30s were modestly wider. Today’s bid was inspired by weak consumer confidence data, while the slide in risk assets also contributed (weak consumer confidence out of the US follows weak Eurozone PMI data; Trump stuck to the script at the UN, but revealed no signs of thawing on China or Iran, while the NY Fed’s repo operations – both the 14-day and the overnight operation – were oversubscribed, hinting that liquidity conditions in money markets might not be a temporary phenomenon, and possibly reflects some other underlying tensions other than the temporary factors cited last week (last week, the crunch in money markets was attributed to corporate tax paying and digesting Treasury issuance). The Treasury’s sale of 2-year notes was solid, stopping through the screens by 1bps. Cover was above recent averages, and the bidder breakdown was also encouraging, seeing primary dealers participation lower, and indirect bidder participation above recent averages. US T-note futures (Z9) settled 20+ higher ticks at 130-23.

subject: US Market Wrap - 24th September 2019: Trump impeachment talk grows; US consumer confidence miss; Trump scolds China at the UN
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries higher, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: US consumer confidence misses; Trump sticks to the script at the UN, scolds China; Trump impeachment probability rises; US/Japan trade deal delayed; PBOC in no rush to add stimulus; Kuroda says BOJ undecided on adding more stimulus; SCOTUK rules against BoJo; Fed O/N and 14-day repo ops oversubscribed.
  • COMING UP: RBNZ Rate Decision, Norwegian Unemployment Rate, US New Home Sales. Pelosi to announce Trump investigation AMC; Nike earnings due AMC.

* MARKET WRAP: Consumer confidence missed expectations, keeping concerns about global growth elevated; President Trump stuck to the script at the UN, did not offer any olive branches to Iran, and there is seemingly no clear sign meaningful progress has been made in US/China trade talks (in fact, Trump again accused China of stealing intellectual property, and said US must have justice), while US/Japan trade talks have hit a snag. The probability of a Trump impeachment is now around 46% according to betting markets, falling from 66% earlier, as Trump announced he will release transcripts of his call with Ukrainian President Zelensky. Additionally, it seems the PBOC is talking down stimulus measures. Havens like Treasuries, JPY, XAU have found bids, while equities have seen downside. However, the ‘risk-off’ signal is not universal, with a lot of EMFX higher, along with antipodes. Crude, meanwhile, is softer ahead of API inventories, with demand-side factors being cited for the weakness. 

* TRUMP IMPEACHMENT: A majority of Democrats are now in favour of impeaching US President Trump, and desks note that the implied probability of a Trump impeachment was as high as 66% today, as derived from betting markets; however once US President Trump announced he would release the transcript of his phone call to Ukrainian President Zelensky, the implied probability fell to 46%. The phone call has been one of the Democrat’s main reasons to call for an impeachment, as a whistle-blower complained about the call. US House Speaker Pelosi is expected to announce aftermarket a formal inquiry into the whistle-blower complaint. Currently, 165 Democrats and 1 independent lawmakers are said to be backing impeachment, Axios reported, with 218 require; the total was 80 in June. Markets have taken the news with caution, with traders noting the uncertainties and increasingly anti-business position of Democrats behind the risk-off, while Democrats are yet unlikely to have read the transcript itself.

* TRUMP UN SPEECH: US President Trump largely stuck to the script in his UN speech, reiterating known stances. He believes a deal can be made with China, though said the US was seeking ’justice’ for intellectual property theft. Trump also suggested the US was monitoring events in Hong Kong, which will likely irritate China (although Trump has still not bought up the Uighur issue in public remarks, something which sources had suggest he might). On Japan, he said that they are looking to finalise a deal before Wednesday. Trump had firm words for Iran, and sanctions would not be lifted. They will be tightened as long as Iran continues its ‘menacing’ behaviour. Elsewhere, his usual calls for other nations to up defence spending, and his anti-immigrant stance were on show. The market digested Trump’s comments with a risk-off feel – while everything he said was largely known, he did not adopt a conciliatory tone on either trade or Iran.

* US CONSUMER CONFIDENCE: Missed expectations, falling to 125.1 against expectations of 133.5; although the headline is still consistent with solid consumption growth, the details were soft, indicating that trade tensions could be filtering into the consumer sector. The sub-indices were weak, with present conditions falling (169 vs 176) as well as expectations falling (95.8 from 106.4), while the differential between jobs plentiful and jobs hard to get fell, auguring poorly for next week’s employment situation report. Inflation expectations also eased slightly to 4.8% from 4.9%. Analysts noted that the weakness mirrors that seen in the University of Michigan’s gauge of consumer confidence, hinting that the pace of consumer spending seen of late will struggle to be sustained, with indicators pointing to slower growth ahead. In its most recent statement, the FOMC upgraded its assessment of household spending, however, today’s consumer confidence data challenges the Fed’s thesis somewhat, and could signal further ate cuts ahead.

* US/CHINA: China has reportedly granted new waivers to several domestic state and private firms which exempts them from retaliatory tariffs on soybeans imported from the US, sources said. The waivers apply to between 2-3mln tonnes of US soybeans; on Monday, reports had suggested that some Chinese companies had bought at least 20 cargoes of US soybeans, or around 1.2mln tonnes.

* PBOC: After recent RRR cuts, a PBOC statement judged that interest rates were now appropriate, and the central bank has ample policy tools. Governor Yi Gang said the central bank was not in a rush to add stimulus, will maintain a prudent monetary policy stance, and will keep debt levels sustainable. While inflationary pressures remain moderate, Yi said the central bank would be patient, stating "we are not in a rush to roll out massive rate cuts or QE like some other central banks." Some desks have noted that the tone of Financial News, the PBOC's official outlet, has become more hawkish relative to the recent State Council meeting. UBS notes that while China definitely wants to support economic growth, policymakers are cautious on current re-leveraging and reheating of the property sector, and UBS therefore argues that the PBOC is now slightly reluctant to conduct another aggressive RRR cut this year, as policymakers attempt to strike a balance between a growing domestic economy and pushing forward necessary reforms, such as deleveraging and cooling the real estate market. Meanwhile, Finance Minister Liu Kun said policymakers will continue to adjust policies on tax cuts and fee cuts, based on assessments, and aims to allocate all local government bond proceeds to projects by the end of October.

* US/JAPAN: The US and Japan may fall short of signing a trade deal this week, NY Times reported, as negotiators grapple with how to resolve US President Trump's threat to place tariffs on cars from Japan; last year, car imports made up around one-third of US' Japanese imports. There were hopes that a trade deal would be signed between the two nations at this week's UN meetings, but instead, the two sides may issue a joint statement, and keep working toward completing an agreement in the coming weeks. Trump has seen the tariffs as leverage in negotiations, though it is also becoming an obstacle to reaching a deal, sources said; Japan has been seeking a commitment from the US not to tariff Japanese cars, and is pushing to include a 'sunset clause' in the trade deal that would cause the deal, as well as any benefits it has delivered to US agricultural producers, to expire if US follows through on threats to impose auto tariffs on Japan.

* GERMAN SEPTEMBER IFO: Although headline business climate rose above expectations (94.6 vs expected 94.4 and prior 94.3), the details still shows the challenges faced by the German economy. Expectations fell to 90.8 from 91.3, mitigating the optimism of the headline. There was a fall in the manufacturing component, though services rebounded (in contrast to Markit's PMI data) Pantheon Macroeconomics said, although added that it has to be careful fitting stories to the data, it appears that the ECB’s recently announced measures have succeeded in providing a modest lift to the current assessment, while expectations are still hampered by unchanged, and elevated, global uncertainty.

* ECB: ECB's de Guindos said the ECB is facing a more protracted economic slowdown than was previously expected (echoing Draghi on Monday), but said there was very little evidence of this priced in by markets. Alluding to liquidity squeezes, the Vice President said that if money market transactions were to occur at higher rates than previously, there could be some upward pressure on certain rates.

* BREXIT: UK Supreme Court has on Tuesday judged that PM Johnson's prorogation of Parliament was unlawful, in a blow to Johnson. House of Commons Speaker Bercow subsequentially announced he would recall Parliament first thing on Wednesday at 11:30 BST, where there will be opportunity for emergency debate applications under SO24 (essentially providing MPs the opportunity to take control of the order paper and therefore the running order of Parliament); however, it is not yet clear on how the Parliamentary proceedings will develop, or how the government intends to proceed. Capital Economics said the decision increases the chances of a delay to Brexit and reduces the chances of a “no deal”. CapEco says there are three ways in which this could influence Brexit: 1) MPs will have more time to try and tighten up the legislation that would force the Prime Minister to delay Brexit to 31st January. 2) It presumably reduces the ability of the government to suspend Parliament again, either before 31st October, or ahead of any further Brexit deadline, thereby allowing Parliament more leeway to prevent a no deal. 3) Johnson could resign as Prime Minister which, again, would reduce the chances of a no deal (although the PM has said he would not). Capital Economics says that, as it stands, the best way for the PM to meet his pledge to leave the EU on 31st October is with a deal, but it notes that two hurdles lie in his way: agreeing a deal with the EU, and then getting it passed through Parliament; the consultancy says that both look very challenging.

* FED: Fed's Kashkari (dove, non-voter) said he pushed for a larger rate cut at the September FOMC; says job market has slowed markedly.

* BOJ: Governor Kuroda said the BOJ was yet undecided on adding more stimulus at its October meeting, adding that the bank was seeking ways to make its yield curve control policy more sustainable, and warned that if the current low-interest rate environment is prolonged further, it will become necessary to pay closer attention to the cost of the BOJ's policies, arguing that any easing would aim to push short- and medium-term rates, without hitting longer-dated yields. Kuroda also reiterated that the central bank stands ready to boost stimulus if the economy risks losing momentum which could impact its price goal, and in determining whether further action is required, the BOJ will examine whether demand is exceeding supply, how keen companies are in raising prices and wages, as well as the evolution of inflation expectations. Deutsche Bank's analysts said that, against the backdrop of the BOJ adding dovish language after the past two meetings (July’s "won’t hesitate", September’s "will re-examine developments") Kuroda’s speech reads a touch hawkish, signalling that he is in no rush to ease, while he also sounded more upbeat on inflation than the market's path.

* RBA: Ahead of next week's policy meeting, RBA Governor Lowe reiterated that he would consider QE in some circumstances but still thinks it is unlikely, Lowe also cited recent evidence which has shown that the economy can sustain lower rates of unemployment and underemployment than previously thought likely. He noted that fundamental factors underpinning the longer-term outlook for the Australian economy remained strong, and the economy has reached a gentle turning point (something he has said recently). The RBA's Board was prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy, and make further progress towards full employment, and achieve the inflation target over time. Looking ahead, Lowe said that inflation was expected to pick up, but will likely remain below the midpoint of the target range for some time. Lowe also noted that the flexibility of labour supply meant that strong rates of employment growth can be sustained without inflation becoming a problem - both positive developments, Lowe said Australia benefits from having both a flexible exchange rate and a flexible labour market, taking comfort in the economy's strong fundamentals. After Lowe's comments, markets continue to price a rate cut next week with 60% certainty (versus around 80% at the end of last week).

* RBNZ PREVIEW: The RBNZ will announce its latest rate decision on Wednesday in which the central bank is expected to keep the Official Cash Rate at 1.00% with a Reuters poll showing unanimous forecasts for the RBNZ to pause on rates, while markets are pricing in a 69% probability for no change in the OCR and 31% chance for a 25bps cut. Click here for full preview.

* WTI (X9) SETTLED USD 1.35 LOWER AT USD 57.29/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLED USD 1.67 LOWER AT USD 63.10/BBL: The demand-side is once again the driver of lower oil prices, after data showed that US consumer confidence fell in September, against expectations of a rise. It could also be indicative that the market is, for now, buying the Saudi line that production will be normalised by next week. Brent prices settled at USD 60.22 on the Friday before Saudi Arabian oil facilities were attacked, rising to a peak of USD 71.95 on the Monday that followed. With Brent prices now falling back to a 63-handle; PVM is surprised that fears of further attacks/retaliations have been subdued, though geopolitical tensions remain elevated with US troops heading to the Middle East, while any diplomatic resolution between US/Iran seems far off. Elsewhere, Russia Energy Minister Novak says the Saudis have not asked Russia to raise oil production; says Russia has capacity to raise oil output by 0.5mln BPD in the short-term.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 20+ HIGHER TICKS AT 130-23. The curve was mixed, at settlement; although yields are lower across the curve, 2s5s, 2s10s and 2s30s spreads are slightly narrower, while 5s10s, 5s30s and 10s30s were modestly wider. Today’s bid was inspired by weak consumer confidence data, while the slide in risk assets also contributed (weak consumer confidence out of the US follows weak Eurozone PMI data; Trump stuck to the script at the UN, but revealed no signs of thawing on China or Iran, while the NY Fed’s repo operations – both the 14-day and the overnight operation – were oversubscribed, hinting that liquidity conditions in money markets might not be a temporary phenomenon, and possibly reflects some other underlying tensions other than the temporary factors cited last week (last week, the crunch in money markets was attributed to corporate tax paying and digesting Treasury issuance). The Treasury’s sale of 2-year notes was solid, stopping through the screens by 1bps. Cover was above recent averages, and the bidder breakdown was also encouraging, seeing primary dealers participation lower, and indirect bidder participation above recent averages.

* 5-YEAR PREVIEW: From a relative-value perspective, the 5-year part of the curve lacks clear set-up ahead of Wednesday's auction, SocGen says, noting that it trades rich in asset swap versus older 5s, though it is cheap on the fly versus 2s and 10s. Last cycles' auction series saw decent internals, despite the selling at the lowest high-yield since October 2016. SocGen has argued that low dealer holdings in the 3-6 year sector should support demand at this week's auction, adding that the current WI is cheap relative to previous outright stop-out rates; the bank says it is positive on the 5s auction.

* S&P 500 -0.8% AT 2967, NASDAQ-100 -1.4% AT 7710, DOW JONES  -0.5% AT 26812; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -1.2%, Consumer Staples  0.3%, Energy  -1.6%, Financials  -0.9%, Health Care  -0.9%, Industrials  -0.6%, Information Technology  -1%, Materials  -1%, Telecommunication Services  -1.3%, Utilities  1.1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) initially traded in the green following an upgrade at Jefferies; the tech behemoth also likely benefitting from a Digi Times article stating its iPhone 11 demand has exceeded expectations in Taiwan. Gains were pared back as it followed Tuesday’s general cautious market tone. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) an outperformer following an upgrade at Goldman Sachs. CarMax (KMX) initially were an outperformer, however, gains reversed as it tracked the overall risk-off tone. The semiconductor index (SOX) initially opened higher also, coinciding with some positive research from RBC, which suggested both NAND and DRAM pricing has bottomed, and are showing signs of a rebound; however it also became susceptible to the overall risk tone and drifted lower throughout the session. AMD (AMD) were under pressure as initial reports suggest it delayed its Ryzen 9 3950 X launch, however AMD announced that it is focusing on meeting strong demand for its Ryzen processes and that it is planning to launch both AMD Ryzen 9 3950 X and 3rd generation threadripper processer family in volume from November. Social media names (FB, TWTR) came under scrutiny again from US President Trump who announced social media companies are weakening the democratic rule. Consumer names (TGT, M, WMT) all hit by poor consumer confidence data, and housing names (LEN, PHM, TOL) firmer following mixed housing data, Case Shiller missed expectations and slowed from the prior however FHFA was firmer, beating expectations. Tesla (TSLA) was pressured as its rival, Nio (NIO) fell 25% after it posted a quarterly drop in sales, citing a cut in subsidies and weak demand for the decline.

* NIKE (NKE) Earnings PRIMER: Nike (NKE) are releasing their Q1 earnings report (June-Aug 31st quarter) tonight at 16:15 ET / 21:15 BST where it is expected to report an EPS of USD 0.70 and a revenue of USD 10.41bln. Expectations for FY EPS are USD 2.90 and FY revenue expected at USD 42.18bln. Click here for full analysis

* FX WRAP: An oversubscribed overnight and 14-day repo operations and weak consumer confidence put the buck under pressure, allowing EUR to trade up. Havens JPY, CHF and XAU benefited from the cautious tone of trading, though other FX more associated with risk-on conditions (AUD, NZD, and EMFX) were firmer; however, BRL was lower as the pension vote in the senate is once again delayed. The pound was up after SCOTUK ruled against PM Johnson’s prorogation, a friendly outcome for pro-Remainers.

subject: US Market Wrap - 24th September 2019: Trump impeachment talk grows; US consumer confidence miss; Trump scolds China at the UN
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries higher, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: US consumer confidence misses; Trump sticks to the script at the UN, scolds China; Trump impeachment probability rises; US/Japan trade deal delayed; PBOC in no rush to add stimulus; Kuroda says BOJ undecided on adding more stimulus; SCOTUK rules against BoJo; Fed O/N and 14-day repo ops oversubscribed.
  • COMING UP: RBNZ Rate Decision, Norwegian Unemployment Rate, US New Home Sales. Pelosi to announce Trump investigation AMC; Nike earnings due AMC.

* MARKET WRAP: Consumer confidence missed expectations, keeping concerns about global growth elevated; President Trump stuck to the script at the UN, did not offer any olive branches to Iran, and there is seemingly no clear sign meaningful progress has been made in US/China trade talks (in fact, Trump again accused China of stealing intellectual property, and said US must have justice), while US/Japan trade talks have hit a snag. The probability of a Trump impeachment is now around 46% according to betting markets, falling from 66% earlier, as Trump announced he will release transcripts of his call with Ukrainian President Zelensky. Additionally, it seems the PBOC is talking down stimulus measures. Havens like Treasuries, JPY, XAU have found bids, while equities have seen downside. However, the ‘risk-off’ signal is not universal, with a lot of EMFX higher, along with antipodes. Crude, meanwhile, is softer ahead of API inventories, with demand-side factors being cited for the weakness. 

* TRUMP IMPEACHMENT: A majority of Democrats are now in favour of impeaching US President Trump, and desks note that the implied probability of a Trump impeachment was as high as 66% today, as derived from betting markets; however once US President Trump announced he would release the transcript of his phone call to Ukrainian President Zelensky, the implied probability fell to 46%. The phone call has been one of the Democrat’s main reasons to call for an impeachment, as a whistle-blower complained about the call. US House Speaker Pelosi is expected to announce aftermarket a formal inquiry into the whistle-blower complaint. Currently, 165 Democrats and 1 independent lawmakers are said to be backing impeachment, Axios reported, with 218 require; the total was 80 in June. Markets have taken the news with caution, with traders noting the uncertainties and increasingly anti-business position of Democrats behind the risk-off, while Democrats are yet unlikely to have read the transcript itself.

* TRUMP UN SPEECH: US President Trump largely stuck to the script in his UN speech, reiterating known stances. He believes a deal can be made with China, though said the US was seeking ’justice’ for intellectual property theft. Trump also suggested the US was monitoring events in Hong Kong, which will likely irritate China (although Trump has still not bought up the Uighur issue in public remarks, something which sources had suggest he might). On Japan, he said that they are looking to finalise a deal before Wednesday. Trump had firm words for Iran, and sanctions would not be lifted. They will be tightened as long as Iran continues its ‘menacing’ behaviour. Elsewhere, his usual calls for other nations to up defence spending, and his anti-immigrant stance were on show. The market digested Trump’s comments with a risk-off feel – while everything he said was largely known, he did not adopt a conciliatory tone on either trade or Iran.

* US CONSUMER CONFIDENCE: Missed expectations, falling to 125.1 against expectations of 133.5; although the headline is still consistent with solid consumption growth, the details were soft, indicating that trade tensions could be filtering into the consumer sector. The sub-indices were weak, with present conditions falling (169 vs 176) as well as expectations falling (95.8 from 106.4), while the differential between jobs plentiful and jobs hard to get fell, auguring poorly for next week’s employment situation report. Inflation expectations also eased slightly to 4.8% from 4.9%. Analysts noted that the weakness mirrors that seen in the University of Michigan’s gauge of consumer confidence, hinting that the pace of consumer spending seen of late will struggle to be sustained, with indicators pointing to slower growth ahead. In its most recent statement, the FOMC upgraded its assessment of household spending, however, today’s consumer confidence data challenges the Fed’s thesis somewhat, and could signal further ate cuts ahead.

* US/CHINA: China has reportedly granted new waivers to several domestic state and private firms which exempts them from retaliatory tariffs on soybeans imported from the US, sources said. The waivers apply to between 2-3mln tonnes of US soybeans; on Monday, reports had suggested that some Chinese companies had bought at least 20 cargoes of US soybeans, or around 1.2mln tonnes.

* PBOC: After recent RRR cuts, a PBOC statement judged that interest rates were now appropriate, and the central bank has ample policy tools. Governor Yi Gang said the central bank was not in a rush to add stimulus, will maintain a prudent monetary policy stance, and will keep debt levels sustainable. While inflationary pressures remain moderate, Yi said the central bank would be patient, stating "we are not in a rush to roll out massive rate cuts or QE like some other central banks." Some desks have noted that the tone of Financial News, the PBOC's official outlet, has become more hawkish relative to the recent State Council meeting. UBS notes that while China definitely wants to support economic growth, policymakers are cautious on current re-leveraging and reheating of the property sector, and UBS therefore argues that the PBOC is now slightly reluctant to conduct another aggressive RRR cut this year, as policymakers attempt to strike a balance between a growing domestic economy and pushing forward necessary reforms, such as deleveraging and cooling the real estate market. Meanwhile, Finance Minister Liu Kun said policymakers will continue to adjust policies on tax cuts and fee cuts, based on assessments, and aims to allocate all local government bond proceeds to projects by the end of October.

* US/JAPAN: The US and Japan may fall short of signing a trade deal this week, NY Times reported, as negotiators grapple with how to resolve US President Trump's threat to place tariffs on cars from Japan; last year, car imports made up around one-third of US' Japanese imports. There were hopes that a trade deal would be signed between the two nations at this week's UN meetings, but instead, the two sides may issue a joint statement, and keep working toward completing an agreement in the coming weeks. Trump has seen the tariffs as leverage in negotiations, though it is also becoming an obstacle to reaching a deal, sources said; Japan has been seeking a commitment from the US not to tariff Japanese cars, and is pushing to include a 'sunset clause' in the trade deal that would cause the deal, as well as any benefits it has delivered to US agricultural producers, to expire if US follows through on threats to impose auto tariffs on Japan.

* GERMAN SEPTEMBER IFO: Although headline business climate rose above expectations (94.6 vs expected 94.4 and prior 94.3), the details still shows the challenges faced by the German economy. Expectations fell to 90.8 from 91.3, mitigating the optimism of the headline. There was a fall in the manufacturing component, though services rebounded (in contrast to Markit's PMI data) Pantheon Macroeconomics said, although added that it has to be careful fitting stories to the data, it appears that the ECB’s recently announced measures have succeeded in providing a modest lift to the current assessment, while expectations are still hampered by unchanged, and elevated, global uncertainty.

* ECB: ECB's de Guindos said the ECB is facing a more protracted economic slowdown than was previously expected (echoing Draghi on Monday), but said there was very little evidence of this priced in by markets. Alluding to liquidity squeezes, the Vice President said that if money market transactions were to occur at higher rates than previously, there could be some upward pressure on certain rates.

* BREXIT: UK Supreme Court has on Tuesday judged that PM Johnson's prorogation of Parliament was unlawful, in a blow to Johnson. House of Commons Speaker Bercow subsequentially announced he would recall Parliament first thing on Wednesday at 11:30 BST, where there will be opportunity for emergency debate applications under SO24 (essentially providing MPs the opportunity to take control of the order paper and therefore the running order of Parliament); however, it is not yet clear on how the Parliamentary proceedings will develop, or how the government intends to proceed. Capital Economics said the decision increases the chances of a delay to Brexit and reduces the chances of a “no deal”. CapEco says there are three ways in which this could influence Brexit: 1) MPs will have more time to try and tighten up the legislation that would force the Prime Minister to delay Brexit to 31st January. 2) It presumably reduces the ability of the government to suspend Parliament again, either before 31st October, or ahead of any further Brexit deadline, thereby allowing Parliament more leeway to prevent a no deal. 3) Johnson could resign as Prime Minister which, again, would reduce the chances of a no deal (although the PM has said he would not). Capital Economics says that, as it stands, the best way for the PM to meet his pledge to leave the EU on 31st October is with a deal, but it notes that two hurdles lie in his way: agreeing a deal with the EU, and then getting it passed through Parliament; the consultancy says that both look very challenging.

* FED: Fed's Kashkari (dove, non-voter) said he pushed for a larger rate cut at the September FOMC; says job market has slowed markedly.

* BOJ: Governor Kuroda said the BOJ was yet undecided on adding more stimulus at its October meeting, adding that the bank was seeking ways to make its yield curve control policy more sustainable, and warned that if the current low-interest rate environment is prolonged further, it will become necessary to pay closer attention to the cost of the BOJ's policies, arguing that any easing would aim to push short- and medium-term rates, without hitting longer-dated yields. Kuroda also reiterated that the central bank stands ready to boost stimulus if the economy risks losing momentum which could impact its price goal, and in determining whether further action is required, the BOJ will examine whether demand is exceeding supply, how keen companies are in raising prices and wages, as well as the evolution of inflation expectations. Deutsche Bank's analysts said that, against the backdrop of the BOJ adding dovish language after the past two meetings (July’s "won’t hesitate", September’s "will re-examine developments") Kuroda’s speech reads a touch hawkish, signalling that he is in no rush to ease, while he also sounded more upbeat on inflation than the market's path.

* RBA: Ahead of next week's policy meeting, RBA Governor Lowe reiterated that he would consider QE in some circumstances but still thinks it is unlikely, Lowe also cited recent evidence which has shown that the economy can sustain lower rates of unemployment and underemployment than previously thought likely. He noted that fundamental factors underpinning the longer-term outlook for the Australian economy remained strong, and the economy has reached a gentle turning point (something he has said recently). The RBA's Board was prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy, and make further progress towards full employment, and achieve the inflation target over time. Looking ahead, Lowe said that inflation was expected to pick up, but will likely remain below the midpoint of the target range for some time. Lowe also noted that the flexibility of labour supply meant that strong rates of employment growth can be sustained without inflation becoming a problem - both positive developments, Lowe said Australia benefits from having both a flexible exchange rate and a flexible labour market, taking comfort in the economy's strong fundamentals. After Lowe's comments, markets continue to price a rate cut next week with 60% certainty (versus around 80% at the end of last week).

* RBNZ PREVIEW: The RBNZ will announce its latest rate decision on Wednesday in which the central bank is expected to keep the Official Cash Rate at 1.00% with a Reuters poll showing unanimous forecasts for the RBNZ to pause on rates, while markets are pricing in a 69% probability for no change in the OCR and 31% chance for a 25bps cut. Click here for full preview.

* WTI (X9) SETTLED USD 1.35 LOWER AT USD 57.29/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLED USD 1.67 LOWER AT USD 63.10/BBL: The demand-side is once again the driver of lower oil prices, after data showed that US consumer confidence fell in September, against expectations of a rise. It could also be indicative that the market is, for now, buying the Saudi line that production will be normalised by next week. Brent prices settled at USD 60.22 on the Friday before Saudi Arabian oil facilities were attacked, rising to a peak of USD 71.95 on the Monday that followed. With Brent prices now falling back to a 63-handle; PVM is surprised that fears of further attacks/retaliations have been subdued, though geopolitical tensions remain elevated with US troops heading to the Middle East, while any diplomatic resolution between US/Iran seems far off. Elsewhere, Russia Energy Minister Novak says the Saudis have not asked Russia to raise oil production; says Russia has capacity to raise oil output by 0.5mln BPD in the short-term.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED 20+ HIGHER TICKS AT 130-23. The curve was mixed, at settlement; although yields are lower across the curve, 2s5s, 2s10s and 2s30s spreads are slightly narrower, while 5s10s, 5s30s and 10s30s were modestly wider. Today’s bid was inspired by weak consumer confidence data, while the slide in risk assets also contributed (weak consumer confidence out of the US follows weak Eurozone PMI data; Trump stuck to the script at the UN, but revealed no signs of thawing on China or Iran, while the NY Fed’s repo operations – both the 14-day and the overnight operation – were oversubscribed, hinting that liquidity conditions in money markets might not be a temporary phenomenon, and possibly reflects some other underlying tensions other than the temporary factors cited last week (last week, the crunch in money markets was attributed to corporate tax paying and digesting Treasury issuance). The Treasury’s sale of 2-year notes was solid, stopping through the screens by 1bps. Cover was above recent averages, and the bidder breakdown was also encouraging, seeing primary dealers participation lower, and indirect bidder participation above recent averages.

* 5-YEAR PREVIEW: From a relative-value perspective, the 5-year part of the curve lacks clear set-up ahead of Wednesday's auction, SocGen says, noting that it trades rich in asset swap versus older 5s, though it is cheap on the fly versus 2s and 10s. Last cycles' auction series saw decent internals, despite the selling at the lowest high-yield since October 2016. SocGen has argued that low dealer holdings in the 3-6 year sector should support demand at this week's auction, adding that the current WI is cheap relative to previous outright stop-out rates; the bank says it is positive on the 5s auction.

* S&P 500 -0.8% AT 2967, NASDAQ-100 -1.4% AT 7710, DOW JONES  -0.5% AT 26812; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -1.2%, Consumer Staples  0.3%, Energy  -1.6%, Financials  -0.9%, Health Care  -0.9%, Industrials  -0.6%, Information Technology  -1%, Materials  -1%, Telecommunication Services  -1.3%, Utilities  1.1%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) initially traded in the green following an upgrade at Jefferies; the tech behemoth also likely benefitting from a Digi Times article stating its iPhone 11 demand has exceeded expectations in Taiwan. Gains were pared back as it followed Tuesday’s general cautious market tone. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) an outperformer following an upgrade at Goldman Sachs. CarMax (KMX) initially were an outperformer, however, gains reversed as it tracked the overall risk-off tone. The semiconductor index (SOX) initially opened higher also, coinciding with some positive research from RBC, which suggested both NAND and DRAM pricing has bottomed, and are showing signs of a rebound; however it also became susceptible to the overall risk tone and drifted lower throughout the session. AMD (AMD) were under pressure as initial reports suggest it delayed its Ryzen 9 3950 X launch, however AMD announced that it is focusing on meeting strong demand for its Ryzen processes and that it is planning to launch both AMD Ryzen 9 3950 X and 3rd generation threadripper processer family in volume from November. Social media names (FB, TWTR) came under scrutiny again from US President Trump who announced social media companies are weakening the democratic rule. Consumer names (TGT, M, WMT) all hit by poor consumer confidence data, and housing names (LEN, PHM, TOL) firmer following mixed housing data, Case Shiller missed expectations and slowed from the prior however FHFA was firmer, beating expectations. Tesla (TSLA) was pressured as its rival, Nio (NIO) fell 25% after it posted a quarterly drop in sales, citing a cut in subsidies and weak demand for the decline.

* NIKE (NKE) Earnings PRIMER: Nike (NKE) are releasing their Q1 earnings report (June-Aug 31st quarter) tonight at 16:15 ET / 21:15 BST where it is expected to report an EPS of USD 0.70 and a revenue of USD 10.41bln. Expectations for FY EPS are USD 2.90 and FY revenue expected at USD 42.18bln. Click here for full analysis

Havens JPY, CHF and XAU benefited from the cautious tone of trading, though other FX more associated with risk-on conditions (AUD, NZD, and EMFX) were firmer; however, BRL was lower as the pension vote in the senate is once again delayed. The pound was up after SCOTUK ruled against PM Johnson’s prorogation, a friendly outcome for pro-Remainers.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar dented as G10 peers strengthen and US consumer confidence weakens
content:
DXY

Marginally softer on the day with the Dollar Index back down below the 98.50 mark as downside seen heading (due to gains across G10 peers) into the US cash open further exacerbated as Fed repo operations saw the overnight and 14-day oversubscribe, in-turn signalling further stress in money markets. Further, disappointing US consumer confidence data only added fuel to the bearish fire and took the DXY down to sub-98.50 levels. DXY looks to end the EU session at near the bottom of 98.44-70 range.

GBP, EUR

Sterling remains one of the G10 winner after the UK Supreme Court dealt a blow to UK PM Johnson after it ruled the decision as a court matter before announcing that the suspension was unlawful. Parliament will now convene at 1130 BST tomorrow, meanwhile ambiguity surrounds whether Labour Leader Corbyn will call a vote of no confidence this week amid mounting pressure, although a Labour spokesperson declined to comment. Aside from that, chances of a Brexit delay have seemingly increased with EU diplomats also admitting that an extension will take pressure off both sides to make compromises, as per BBC’s Adler, however, PM Johnson has noted that he will not abandon his attempt to take the UK out of the bloc on October 31st. Cable remains near intraday highs around its 21 WMA (1.2490) having earlier tested 1.2500 to the upside after trading within a 1.2415-2500 range. Meanwhile the Euro has reclaimed 1.1000 to the upside with aid from a weakening USD amid the aforementioned reasons after deriving little impetus from the Ifo measures which mostly topped estimates (ex-expectations), although the institute noted that the outlook for the coming months has deteriorated and the domestic economy is likely to shrink in Q3 and stagnate in Q4, a similar comment mate by IHS yesterday. EUR/USD is poised to end the EU session near intra-day highs within a 1.0985-1015 range.

AUD, NZD

The Aussie has held onto a bulk of its Lowe-induced gains and is poised to close the EU session not far off the 0.6800 mark after the governor highlighted that fundamental factors underpinning the longer-term outlook for the Australian economy remain strong and economy has reached a gentle turning point, a comment made at the last speech which signals that the Central Bank could stand pat on at the next meeting on October 1st. AUD/USD remains near close to the top of today’s 0.6766-0.6805 ahead of resistance at 0.6810. Elsewhere, the Kiwi has derived strength ahead of tonight’s RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision with expectations with a Reuters poll showing unanimous forecasts for the RBNZ to pause on rates at 1.00% after over-delivering at the last meeting (full preview available in the RANsquawk research suite). As for the cross, AUD/NZD has receded further from the 1.08 level and resides around 1.0750 heading into the European close.

JPY

Marginally firmer on the back of a weaker Greenback and as the geopolitical landscape remains volatile as US President Trump refrained from de-escalating tensions, with Iran as sanctions will remain and tighten as long as Iran’s behaviour continues. USD/JPY is poised to the end the session around the 107.50 level having visited (thus far) an intra-day band of 107.40-80.

EM

The Lira staged another recovery with strength attributed to media reports that the US is said to make a new offer to Turkey regarding F-35s and Patriots system after the two Presidents’ phone call over the weekend. USD/TRY fell from an intraday high of 5.7208 to a current low of 5.6735 after breaching its 55 MDA at 5.6779 and ahead of its 50 DMA at 5.6705.

ANALYSIS: UK Supreme Court decision increases chances of a Brexit delay, reduces the chances of a no deal, Capital Economics says
analysis_details:
UK Supreme Court has on Tuesday judged that PM Johnson's prorogation of Parliament was unlawful, a blow to PM Johnson. Capital Economics says the decision increases the chances of a delay to Brexit, and reduces the chances of a no deal. CapEco says there are three ways in which this could influence Brexit:

1) If Parliament does indeed resume in the next few days, then MPs will have more time to try and tighten up the legislation that would force the Prime Minister to delay Brexit to 31st January.  

2) It presumably reduces the ability of the government to suspend Parliament again, either before 31st October, or ahead of any further Brexit deadline, thereby allowing Parliament more leeway to prevent a no deal.  

3) Johnson could resign as Prime Minister which, again, would reduce the chances of a no deal (although the PM has said he would not).

Capital Economics says that, as it stands, the best way for the PM to meet his pledge to leave the EU on 31st October is with a deal, but it notes that two hurdles lie in his way: agreeing a deal with the EU, and then getting it passed through Parliament; the consultancy says that both look very challenging.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • UK Supreme Court deem PM Johnson’s parliament suspension as unlawful, GBP and Gilt whipsawed
  • EU Court rules that Alphabet's Google (GOOG) does not have to apply the right to be forgotten globally
  • US President Trump said he will discuss Iran in his UN speech today at 10:15ET
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Consumer Confidence, New Zealand Trade, UN General Assembly begins, ECB’s de Guindos, Norges Bank’s Matsen and BoE’s Carney. Supply from the US

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded indecisively following a similar close on Wall St where the major indices spent the day steadily recouping the opening losses brought on by weak Eurozone PMI data. ASX 200 (U/C) was choppy as outperformance in gold stocks and resilience in financials were counterbalanced by losses across the broader market, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) remained afloat on return from the extended weekend but with gains capped by a choppy currency and as officials scrambled to finalize a US-Japan trade deal amid uncertainty regarding auto tariffs. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) traded positively after continued PBoC liquidity efforts and as the central bank suggested there was still ample monetary policy tools, although advances were initially limited by the trade-related overhang as participants mulled over the recent ebbs and flows of the US-China trade saga ahead of next month’s high level talks. Finally, 10yr JGBs gained on return from the holiday closure amid the recent temperamental US-China trade headlines and indecisive risk tone in the region, while the BoJ were also present in the market today for JPY 810bln of JGBs in the belly to the short-end.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0729 vs. Exp. 7.0838 (Prev. 7.0734)

PBoC said interest rate levels are appropriate and that China has ample monetary policy tools as well as relatively big policy room. There were also comments from PBoC Governor Yi Gang that China will maintain prudent monetary policy and will not resort to flood-like stimulus, while he added there is in no rush to take big policy easing steps. (Newswires)

China’s Finance Minister Liu Kun said they will adjust policies on tax and fee cuts based on assessments, while he added China is aiming to allocate all local government bond proceeds to projects by end of next month. In related news, China NDRC Vice Chairman Ning stated that China will step up efforts to stabilize growth. (Newswires)

China has given new waivers to several domestic state/private companies for tariff free US soybean purchases. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin confirmed the Chinese delegation visit to US farm states was delayed at request of US and stated that China Vice Premier Liu He will visit next week for discussions, although Mnuchin later commented that he thinks talks with China will resume in 2 weeks. However, US Agriculture Secretary Perdue said the US asked China to purchase more than 20mln tonnes of soybeans but noted there were no commitments from China last week and that he did not know why the farm visits were cancelled. (Newswires/Fox Business News)

Japan’s Foreign Minister Motegi said trade deal negotiations with US finished and that he doesn't see much delay from goal of signing deal by end of the month, while a Foreign Ministry spokesman also said there is still have time to agree to a trade deal with US by end of the month. However, earlier reports suggested a deal may be delayed due to a disagreement regarding the auto tariffs and that an agreement will not be ready to sign when Japanese PM Abe meets US President Trump on Wednesday as it is still undergoing legal checks with the sides to sign separate documents confirming a final agreement. (Newswires)

US

House Democrat leaders have reportedly called for a caucus meeting today at 1600ET to discuss questions of impeachment. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said we're getting along well with North Korea and maybe we will be able to make a deal or maybe not. South Korea spy agency said US-North Korea working level talks will take place in 2-3 weeks and a summit is possible by year-end, while it added North Korea’s leader Kim could attend Korea-ASEAN summit in Busan in November. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he will discuss Iran in his UN speech today, while he added the US have a lot of pressure on Iran and that he is not looking for a mediator on Iran – Trump is scheduled to speak at 10:15ET (Newswires)

Iran President Rouhani said our message to the world is peace and stability, although there were earlier comments from a senior official that Iran will never yield to the US and the US should lift sanctions if it wants to reduce tensions. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Supreme Court has ruled that the poroguation of parlimanet is a legal matter, and that the poroguation was unlawful. As such, the poroguation is void and it is up to Parliament as to the next step. Subsequently, House of Commons speaker Bercow says the House should reconvene as a matter of urgency and he will therefore be consulting party leaders shortly. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson has reportedly not ruled out proroguing parliament and has repeated that he will not resign; note, these repors were prior to the Supreme Court decision. (Newswires/Times)

UK Opposition Labour Leader Corbyn won three votes at the Parties annual conference; as such, the Labour Party are now committed to opposing a general election, renegotiating a Brexit deal with the EU and then putting the deal to the public via a referendum. The party will determine whether to support the deal or not after negotiations have concluded. (Newswires/Times)

UK PM Johnson is to tell US and Canadian business leaders that post-Brexit Britain will roll out the red carpet for investors and will take advantage of post-Brexit freedoms including new tax allowances on investment, according to speech extracts. (Newswires)

UK government official said PM Johnson was clear in meeting with EU's Tusk that a Northern Ireland only backstop was not a solution the UK could accept, while the official added we believe we have put forward detailed proposals to get the process moving along and want to see that the EU are ready to engage seriously with the ideas we put forward. (Newswires)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Sep) 94.6 vs. Exp. 94.4 (Prev. 94.3)

- German Ifo Expectations New (Sep) 90.8 vs. Exp. 91.8 (Prev. 91.3)

- German Ifo Curr Conditions New (Sep) 98.5 vs. Exp. 97 (Prev. 97.3; Revised 97.4)

German Economy Minister Altmaier says the growth forces in the German economy have deteriorated but it is not in a recession. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European Bourses (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) are modestly firmer, albeit off highs, in tentative trade, following a mixed AsiaPac session. The FTSE 100 is the underperformer, under pressure from sterling strength after the UK Supreme Court ruled UK PM Johnson’s decision to prorogue parliament unlawful and, as such, prorogation voided. While stocks are mostly higher, the more defensive Utilities (+1.0%), Health Care (+0.9%) and Consumer Staples (+0.5%) sectors outperform, indicative of continued apprehension in wake of yesterday’s weak EZ PMI data, although the more risk sensitive IT and Financial are also higher. Materials (-0.5%) and Energy (-0.4%) are the laggards, with the latter pressure by lower crude prices. In terms of individual movers; Aviva (+0.8%) is higher on reports the Co. is looking to sell its Singapore and Vietnam businesses in a deal which could be valued at USD 2.5bln. The fixed income complex is subdued thus far, ahead of further Central Bank speakers and the UNGA. In terms of newsflow this morning saw the Ifo release which was a slightly mixed release and as such did not garner much of a response; comments around the release, while interesting, were largely in-line with yesterday’s IHS comments on the prospect of a Q3 stagnation. Elsewhere, UK debt is the main mover of the day on the Supreme Court’s ruling that the prorogation of parliament was unlawful and as such is void, on this ruling Gilts dropped to a low of 133.12 (-60 ticks) before pairing back most of the move and in fact surpassing pre-announcement levels, as the next steps are very unclear. Following the ruling House of Commons speaker Bercow has stated that the House should convene immediately, and other political parties are capitalising on the opportunity to call for Johnson’s resignation. Looking ahead the session for Gilts will likely remain dominated by the parliamentary back-and-forth, though BoE’s Carney is due to speak late doors for the European session. Stateside, focus will be on the UNGA and Trump’s comments, particularly those pertaining to Iran. Elsewhere, a relatively quiet US session with a few data prints scheduled and the first of this weeks’ supply in the form of USD 40bln 2-year auction.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent prices are weaker this morning on a rather tentative session thus far on a lack of specific newsflow for the complex, but notably ahead of the UNGA where US President Trump has stated he is to discuss Iran in his speech. He has also added that the US has lots of pressure on Iran, which does follow from the instigation of sanctions on the Iranian Bank by the US; as such, focus today will be on the remarks from Trump and if there is any reference to further sanctions or the prospect of more forceful action. In terms of scheduling proceedings at the UN are to formally begin at around 13:00BST with President Trump scheduled to arrive at the UN headquarters around 14:30BST. Elsewhere, focus turns to tonight’s API release where expectations are form a 0.6mln/bbl draw; though, ING note that the result may surprise market expectations due to the number of storm related refinery disruptions that have occurred recently. In terms of metals, Gold is little changed hovering around the USD 1520/oz mark within a tight USD 1.0/oz range for the session; ahead of risk factors including the UNGA and a number of Central Bank speakers. Separately, copper prices are overall little changed, retaining their non-committal tone from the Asia-Pac session; though the metal does remain comfortably above the USD 2.62/lb mark.

subject: RBA Governor Lowe says fundamental factors underpinning the longer-term outlook for the Australian economy remain strong, economy has reached a gentle turning point
content:
• The Board is prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy, make further progress towards full employment, and achieve the inflation target over time.
  • Looking ahead, inflation is expected to pick up, but to remain below the midpoint of the target range for some time to come.
  • On the domestic front, there has been an accumulation of evidence over recent times that the economy can sustain lower rates of unemployment and underemployment than previously thought likely.
  • The flexibility of labour supply also means that strong rates of employment growth can be sustained without inflation becoming a problem. These are both positive developments.
  • We benefit from having both a flexible exchange rate and a flexible labour market. So, our fundamentals are strong.
  • Link to speech

UK SUPREME COURT SUMMARY: Supreme Court has ruled that prorogation of parliament is a matter of the court and ruled the suspension as unlawful, it is now up to the speakers of the respective houses to decide to recall MPs
reaction_details: • GBP/USD earlier touched an intra-day high of 1.2487 although the pair then returned to pre-announced levels of around 1.2450 amid unclarity regarding the next steps alongside some profit taking
analysis_details: With prorogation defeated, UK MPs will return to their seats and the parliamentary session will continue. Parliament has already passed the Benn bill, which forces PM Johnson to request an extension should he fail to get a deal with the EU at the EC Summit on 17-18 October, so in a sense, much of the heavy lifting by anti-no deal MPs in stopping a no deal outcome has already been done. However, with parliament back in session, an anti-no deal majority could continue to frustrate government efforts to find a deal with the EU/try to force a no deal.

subject: UK Supreme Court rules that the prorogation of parliament is void, and that it is up to the speakers of parliament to decide what is to be done next
UK Supreme Court rules UK PM Johnson's prorogation of parliament as unlawful
UK Supreme Court rules UK PM Johnson's prorogation of parliament as unlawful
UK Supreme Court rules that no justification for such extreme action has been heard, Government have not explained why it was necessary to halt parliament for 5-weeks
UK Supreme Court rules that this was not a normal prorogation, not a normal suspension of parliament, prolonged suspension of parliament took place in exceptional circumstances
UK Supreme Court rules that the prorogation of parliament is a matter for the judges, decision unanimous
reaction_details: The pound spiked higher, as the higher probability of the return of parliament lowers the perceived probability of a no deal Brexit outcome; GBP shot up from 1.2455 to 1.2485. However, in the minutes after the announcement of the official decision, Cable pared back the entire move, and now sits at pre-announcement levels.
analysis_details: By deciding that the ruling is justiciable, the Supreme Court has opened up the door to ruling on whether or not UK PM Johnson’s decision to prorogue parliament was lawful or not. This is seen as a defeat for the government, as they wanted the Court to rule that the prorogation case was not justiciable, which would have automatically enabled the government to continue as planned with prorogation until 14th October. Due to the fact that this decision brings the defeat of prorogation, and the return of parliament, one step closer, this is seen as a positive for the pound as having anti-no deal MPs sitting make no deal less likely.

subject: EXPLAINER: UK Supreme Court set to decide on legality of Johnson parliamentary prorogation
analysis_details:
What is happening? Today at 10.30am BST, the UK Supreme Court rules the lawfulness of UK PM Johnson’s decision to prorogue parliament until October 14th.

Possible outcomes: First, the Supreme Court will rule on whether or not prorogation is a matter for the court to decide (as a reminder, the English court ruled that is was not). If the government wins this step, then the prorogation of parliament will continue as planned until October 14th. If the Supreme Court deems that it is within their powers to intervene, the next question they will decide upon is whether or not UK PM Johnson acted unlawfully in his prorogation of parliament. Again, should the decision at this stage go the governments way, nothing changes. If the government loses, Johnson could be forced to recall parliament, which could then remain in session as if it had never been prorogued, although some reports suggesting it would be down to the speakers of both houses (Lords and Commons) to decide how to proceed. Depending on the court’s reasoning for making the decision, the ruling might open the possibility of a further prorogation of Parliament in a different, lawful way (note: over the weekend UK Foreign Minister Raab refused to rule out the possibility that parliament could be prorogued again).

What are the implications for Brexit? Parliament have already approved the Benn Bill, which obliges the PM to request an extension to Article 50 should the Prime Minister not have secured a deal with the EU by the end of the EC Summit (17-18 Oct), so in some senses, the heavy lifting has already been done. However, with Parliament back in session, an anti-hard Brexit majority could continue to push further anti-no deal legislation, making it more difficult for Boris Johnson to fulfil his “do or die” pledge.

Note: Normally Parliament does not sit anyway at this time of the year, as the major parties hold their annual conferences. It is unclear how a resumption of the parliamentary session would coincide with the Conservative Party Conference, which will be held on Monday the 30th of September.

Riksbank's Governor Ingves says the Riksbank is aware of the weaker sentiment and the low level of interest rates abroad; added that the rate would likely be increased at a very slow rate over the period ahead
content:
• Regarding the September decision to leave rates unchanged, noted that Sweden has had good economic development and inflation in-line with expectations
  • Remains possible to increase the rate at the end of the year/beginning of next
  • Link to Speech
analysis_details:
• Over the last week we have had a plethora of commentary out of the Riksbank. Firstly, the Bank’s minutes on September 17th highlighted that in-spite of developments occurring largely as expected board members have stressed that sentiment has deteriorated and as such the risk of a slowdown has increased.
  • In terms of recent comments from Ingves and Jansson, within the minutes Ingves stated that inflation is largely in-line and that it’s too early to determine any conclusions from expansionary policy elsewhere. Subsequently, Ingves has largely stuck to his view from the minutes.
  • For reference, the next Riksbank meeting takes place on October 23rd and the chance of a 25bp cut to -0.50% at this meeting is 16.1%.

subject: Riksbank’s Jansson says that Inflation is fairly low, inflation expectations have shown worrying tendencies and I see no appreciable upside risks for inflation
content:
• Over the last week we have had a plethora of commentary out of the Riksbank. Firstly, the Bank’s minutes on September 17th highlighted that in-spite of developments occurring largely as expected board members have stressed that sentiment has deteriorated and as such the risk of a slowdown has increased.
  • In terms of recent comments, within the minutes; Jansson took a more downbeat tone saying, given inflation forecasts, it would be reasonable to refrain from a rate increase at years end
  • Since then, Jansson has since commented that the risk picture is looking very bad and there is no upside to the economy; citing poor employment data and low inflation. Although, these pessimistic comments were caveated somewhat as he added that there is still some way to go until we turn to a easing bias .
  • For reference, the next Riksbank meeting takes place on October 23rd and the chance of a 25bp cut to -0.50% at this meeting is 16.1%.
  • Further declines in inflation will play a large role in his thinking

Link to Speech

Aviva (AV/ LN) – Co. is reportedly looking to sell its Singapore and Vietnam businesses in a deal which could be valued at USD 2.5bln. Allianz (ALV GY), Nippon Life and MS&AD Insurance (8725 JT) are reportedly in a race to buy the businesses, sources state. (Newswires)

24th September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) traded positive after continued PBoC liquidity efforts and as the central bank suggested there was still ample monetary policy tools, although advances were initially limited by the trade-related overhang as participants mulled over the recent ebbs and flows of the US-China trade saga ahead of next month’s high level talks.
